caption: The Guimet Museum in Paris is a must-visit for anyone passionate about Asian art and culture. Its extensive collection spans centuries and features treasures from China, Japan, India, Southeast Asia and beyond. From intricate Buddhist statues to delicate ceramics and textiles, every exhibit showcases extraordinary craftsmanship and rich history. The serence atmosphere and beautifully curated displays allow visitors to immerse themselves in the stories behind each piece. The Guimet Museum offers a captivating journey through Asia’s artistic heritage right in the heart of Paris.

The most complete museum about Southeast Asia, this museum is incredible. Lot's of the artefacts from Southeast Asia and India, shown how strong the connection between this area in the past.  You can visit the museum with permanent exhibition and temporary exhibition. This museum is a great museum. To reach the museum not far from the metro station, you will not lost.

We visited this museum by chance but it had a free to attend exhibition and it was great.  The Guimet Museum (Musée national des arts asiatiques Guimet) in Paris is one of the most significant museums dedicated to Asian art in the world. It houses an extensive collection of artifacts from across Asia, including works from China, Japan, India, Southeast Asia, and Central Asia.  The museum's collection spans thousands of years, showcasing religious art, sculptures, ceramics, paintings, and textiles. It includes significant pieces of Buddhist art, Hindu sculptures, and works from ancient Asian civilizations.  We got to see the Chinese porcelain exhibition.  There is also a free to use toilet in the lower floor.

A magnificent and unique building housing a vast collection of Asian art. The exterior just cannot be ignored, adorned as it is with Japanese style animals poking out from holes in the bright red construction. A fascinating view, unexpected in Paris.

It is a very nice museum with a collection rangin from afghanistan to japan. I visited two temporary exhibitions, the gold of ming and the steppes of Kazakhstan. The latter was extremely short but the first one was a lot kore detail albeit still a short but a wonderful exhibition. Would deginitely recommend visiting here if you are staying in paris for more than a week.

The Musée Guimet, or Guimet Museum, is a renowned museum in Paris, France, dedicated to Asian art and culture. Founded in 1889 by industrialist Émile Guimet, it houses one of the largest and most comprehensive collections of Asian art outside Asia.  The museum’s exhibits span thousands of years, showcasing artifacts from regions such as China, Japan, India, Southeast Asia, and the Himalayas.  Highlights include exquisite Buddhist sculptures, ancient ceramics, and sacred art. Located near the Trocadéro, the Musée Guimet is a cultural treasure, offering deep insights into the rich artistic traditions and histories of Asia.

One of the top 3 Asian art museums I’ve ever visited! Such a fabulous quality broad range of artworks. They rival the bodhisattvas I have seen in Korea and Japan.  Was about 14 euros to enter. Very well lit and presented collection. Spent about 2.5 hours there. Can’t say enough great things just go go go!

This museum needs better A/C on hot summer days for its upper floors.  Well lit with appropriate space. The top also has a lovely cafe for a cooler day,  Don't miss the circular domed Zen library in one of the upper floors. The general Asian collection  has some unusual things that make it worth the visit. A highlight on the first floor is a great deal of wonderful architectural elements and sculpture taken out of SE Asian cities. Use the model on the first floor to see where sculpture actually stood in the city-- and admire the scale of things from over looks on the second floor.

Surprisingly large space once inside and exploring. Not crowded and very interesting if you have any interest in the art or history of asia.  A lot of exhibits missing an English translation, but you only need to pick out a few key French words to get the idea, a good excuse to practise.  Clean and modern space with interesting architecture in it's own right
Visit this museum if you want to know about the Silk Road and the history of Asian Countries. A very beautiful museum.

A beautiful museum and well presented collection which is all the more pleasant because unlike the Louvre or Musée d'Orsay it isn't rammed with people to the point where you can't even move comfortably around the galleries.  Here I almost had galleries to myself and it was such a tranquil and centring experience.  The temporary exhibition on Chinese ceramics is fantastic, as is the contemplation room on the top floor.

I liked this museum. I enjoyed the fact that there is not many people so I took my time to walk around and check all the art. It’s free if you are under 26, if not is 13 euros! I think is a hidden gem.

If someone wants to know the true history of Asia then this is not the museum one should visit. This museum belongs to PRC (China) not France anymore. This Museum is concrete building to spin money & do propaganda of Chinese narratives.  Completely not acceptable! BOYCOTTE MUSEUM GUIMET.

Almost a refreshing change from European cultures and history to step into the Guimet. Having lived in and visited many parts of Asia it was almost a trip through memory lane, but there was a bit of confusion as to how to best look through the venue. With items in collections by country it didn't offer any flow and it was difficult to know which way to walk to best view all of the collections. I was also a little disappointed as I have heard that the Guimet owns one of the 2 scrolls that are thought to represent Hokusai's final works, "Dragon" which I was lucky enough to see on display next to its partner "Tiger in the Rain" in Tokyo in 2019. There is nothing about it mentioned and it is definitely not on display. Overall the collection felt like just that, a collection of bits and pieces rather than a journey through the cultures that make up Asia.
Super interesting! There was a strike going on against it in front of the museum tho

Once a great museum with its own pride. Now they are rewriting the history or changing the narrative of nations by taking the bribery from China. Shame on you Guimet Museum for erasing the identity of Tibet and diluting our narrative by putting us under the shadow of Himalayan regions.

Surprising Museum, far East history and arts, blending archeology and modern art. Unique pieces, unusual for citizens from any other non-colonialist country...  Attached pictures speak by themselves. I had been in Easter weekend and no queues nor crowd. It could be improved in explainations. Close to Trocadero, so few steps from famous spots in Paris.

Fantastic collections of art from the Far East. Everything is very well displayed. The Cambodian collection is one of the largest and finest in the world. Indian, Japanese and Chinese art are also very well represented but there's also Tibetan, Nepalese, Vietnamese departments. Definitely worth the visit
The quality of each art piece at the Guimet museum is of an exceptional level. M Guimet had an eye for both historic importance and beauty. This is on of my favorite museums in the world.

Place need to verified before u will visit 🙏🏼there is no place called Xizang it’s TIBET. Museum is the place where everyone wants to know the truth about everything happened in past. Here lots of upcoming future kids want to get knowledge from here and the every ages want to know the truth and knowledge about past things from TIBET COUNTRY. REQUESTING DONT INFLUENCE BY CHINESE 🙏🏼

I found this hidden gem in Paris that is quite often overlooked. It is a perfect place to dive inside Asian art and architecture. It was a really refreshing experience that took me out of the European culture for a moment. I would definitely suggest visiting it.

Is dedicated to Asian art, focusing on the cultures of East, Southeast, South and Central Asia. The collection includes a diverse range of artifacts such as sculptures, ceramics, textiles, and religious objects from various Asian civilizations. There were some rooms that were closed during my visit.

The museum must stop working under China’s pressure and prioritize truth, integrity, and respect for cultural diversity. We demand the immediate restoration of “Tibet” in all references to its artifacts and history. Museums have a responsibility to preserve and accurately represent history, not dilute it.
Wonderful collection, one day is hardly enough to admire all the pieces. Nice rooftop bar and restaurant, the temporary exhibitions are also worth it!
Great place to learn about Asian art with an amazing rooftop.
Beautiful big museum I couldn’t finish it in one day so I went back the next day but definitely worth it. Also there’s a bookshop and a place to put your belongings near the exist/entrance.
Good museum dedicated to Asian arte, most Chinese but with India, Cambodia, Japan and Korean rooms too. Unfortunately rooms dedicated to Korean and Japan were close to reorganize.
Lovely collection, well displayed in spacious well lit surroundings. The Japanese and Chinese collections are exquisite. The temporary exhibition on Ming dynasty gold ornaments was out of this world.

Deceptively small, but actually grand with several floors of exhibits, a 13 minute film, special side exhibits. cafe, super clean bathroom. Plus, it's air conditioned. Easy to follow rooms showcase different Asian art organised by countries. Each room is quiet, clean, spacious and nicely presented without clutter. Maybe start at the very top level slowly and progressivley descend as you accelerate to the outside before it closes?
Beautiful museum, and it's free for under 25 EU citizens. Worth visiting!
Beautiful and rare art from Tibet. Museums play such an important role remembering us the past, to avoid us repeating mistakes, simple mistakes like erasing a country from existence for example.

It's always with intense pleasure & curiosity that I get myself drowned in 1 of the most beautiful & well documented asian art museum in the world, musée "Emile GUIMET"..... a must visit if you end up somewhat in Paris.... 😉

This isn’t a very popular museum but yet a great one to visit should you have the time. It has a pretty good collection of Chinese pottery, and artifacts from Korea and Japan. Additionally some very good collection from Cambodia and Thailand. The breadth of the collection, specially the Chinese pottery, Khmer sculptures and the Gandhara art are comparable to the Asian Civilisations Museum of Singapore. The collection from Cambodia and one Buddha sculpture from Borbudur, Indonesia does raise an imp question - whether these temples pieces should be returned to its country of origin, or at the very least, whether citizens of these countries should be allowed free admission

Very nice museum display eastern art and sculpture. The current exhibition of monochrome porcelain is well worth a visit.  The permanent collection is fantastic and their Chinese collection of porcelain is among the best I’ve seen. Highly recommended also to enjoy some food at the rooftop Korean fusion restaurant, it was very tasty and combined with an excellent view of Paris and the Eiffel Tower it can’t go wrong
Very inspiring positive place, beautiful collection

My favorite museum in Paris, and one of the best Asian Art collections in the world, if not the best.  The scale of the Khmer stone carvings and the SE Asian and Himalayan bronzes is extraordinary, and they are unlike anything else you can see outside of visiting Asian temples in person.  We had advance tickets, and there was a bit of a queue, but it was pretty small, and the Guimet is a blissfully uncrowded museum, even before Covid.  There is a lot to see in the main building, and if you want to visit the Japanese annex (with garden), the hours are odd and it isn't the easiest place to find, located in an old mansion down the street from the Guimet ( Hôtel d'Heidelbach 19, Avenue d'Iéna).

A beautiful place with fine examples of Asian art. A great inspiration for design and some very sensitively done sculptures. It is quite quiet if you're looking for a place to sketch in peace or just sit in contemplation. Just over the road from the Palais de Tokio.

Incredible collection, most of the sculpture is exposed to the viewer allowing you to get very close to it so that you can see them in great detail. There’s definitely a mystical element to being so close to these ancient stones, what a treat! It could definitely benefit from more explanatory text, and English translations. The main collection is from Cambodia (which was a French colony 😅) but the Chinese collection is also quite dense. Very little from Japan. The basement restaurant is definitely not an attraction, which is a shame cause it’s not easy getting a snack in the area. Overall, superb collection, great wide spaces, a great trip in space and time.
